column4: sorry if this is a silly question, but where is the reboot option in ubuntu 9.10/Gnome?
oh, found it!
yeha, I just noticed the icon near my username
it wasn't obvious at first tho
anyone got any recommendations for the best theme for ubuntu/Gnome ?
alternatively any suggestions on how to make the desktop better for gnome
install kde,   j/k
thanks
check in the control panel and under ... either services or session, whetre it shows the services running at boot, and click on Start if it's stopped
hi there.  I don't have a window manager installed ;)
I've installed swat and there is an entry for it in inetd.conf  - swat  stream tcp nowait.400 root /usr/sbin/tcpd /usr/sbin/swat
you know, I don't see it on my end... no as a default service
check VCoolio's line, I think -> sudo /etc/init.d/inetd restart;  may do it
check VCoolio's line, I think -> sudo /etc/init.d/inetd restart;  may do it  <---
did you try that?   if inetd   is there, I think the 'restart' argument will get it rolling
no, there is no script with that name

since you have no window manager.. how about installing -> sudo apt-get sysv-rc-conf;  is a console bootup services utility, and you can stop/start/restart/remove any from there with just + or - presses
I have chkconfig, which i prefer.  But it wasn't really that I didn't expect it to start on boot - but more that I didn't know how to start it without booting
you can do that in open office Writer
hi  - you can't seem to do it with one click in ooo writer, can you?
sure, type in, your text, select it, then go to Format > Character, the highlighted text will be the 'preview' used and you can click your way through the fonts
